moves: 1. e4 c6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 dxe4 4. Nxe4 Nd7 5. Nf3 Ngf6 6. Ng3 e6 7. Bd3 c5 8. O-O Be7 9. c3 O-O 10. Qe2 b6 11. Ne5 Bb7 12. f4 cxd4 13. cxd4 Nb8
comment:
With the idea of
recycling the Knight with Nb8-c6 to attack the Pd4 or to force the exchange
with the Knight in e5, believing that in such a way the position will improve.

moves: 1. e4 c6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 dxe4 4. Nxe4 Nd7 5. Nf3 Ngf6 6. Ng3 e6 7. Bd3 c5 8. O-O Be7 9. c3 O-O 10. Qe2 b6 11. Ne5 Bb7 12. f4 cxd4 13. cxd4 Nb8 14. Be3 g6
comment:
? - Levenfish, in the Tournament book,
wrote: "Illogical move. It was necessary to continue with Nb8-c6 in agreement
with the prepared plan. Probably White would have replied with Rad1 and only
now g7-g6 would have been good, with the reply Bd3-b1. Probably, against some
other Master, the same position could have been reached by move transposition,
but against Panov, brilliant attacking player, the move in the text is a
mistake. The early castle weakening gives White the idea for a combination."

moves: 1. e4 c6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 dxe4 4. Nxe4 Nd7 5. Nf3 Ngf6 6. Ng3 e6 7. Bd3 c5 8. O-O Be7 9. c3 O-O 10. Qe2 b6 11. Ne5 Bb7 12. f4 cxd4 13. cxd4 Nb8 14. Be3 g6 15. f5
comment: ! - You don't know who I am! 15...

nervousness of my opponent (!) who was in zeitnot did not allow me to think
adequately on the position.
